member.name: T:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions
member.summary: Specifies the behavior for a task that is created by using the or method.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions.AttachedToParent
member.summary: Specifies that the continuation, if it is a child task, is attached to a parent in the task hierarchy. The continuation can be a child task only if its antecedent is also a child task. By default, a child task (that is, an inner task created by an outer task) executes independently of its parent. You can use the option so that the parent and child tasks are synchronized. Note that if a parent task is configured with the option, the option in the child task has no effect, and the child task will execute as a detached child task. For more information, see Attached and Detached Child Tasks.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions.DenyChildAttach
member.summary: Specifies that any child task (that is, any nested inner task created by this continuation) that is created with the option and attempts to execute as an attached child task will not be able to attach to the parent task and will execute instead as a detached child task. For more information, see Attached and Detached Child Tasks.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions.ExecuteSynchronously
member.summary: Specifies that the continuation task should be executed synchronously. With this option specified, the continuation runs on the same thread that causes the antecedent task to transition into its final state. If the antecedent is already complete when the continuation is created, the continuation will run on the thread that creates the continuation. If the antecedent's is disposed in a block ( in Visual Basic), a continuation with this option will run in that block. Only very short-running continuations should be executed synchronously. Because the task executes synchronously, there is no need to call a method such as to ensure that the calling thread waits for the task to complete.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions.HideScheduler
member.summary: Specifies that tasks created by the continuation by calling methods such as or see the default scheduler () rather than the scheduler on which this continuation is running as the current scheduler.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions.LazyCancellation
member.summary: In the case of continuation cancellation, prevents completion of the continuation until the antecedent has completed.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions.LongRunning
member.summary: Specifies that a continuation will be a long-running, course-grained operation. It provides a hint to the that oversubscription may be warranted.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions.None
member.summary: When no continuation options are specified, specifies that default behavior should be used when executing a continuation. The continuation runs asynchronously when the antecedent task completes, regardless of the antecedent's final property value. It the continuation is a child task, it is created as a detached nested task.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions.NotOnCanceled
member.summary: Specifies that the continuation task should not be scheduled if its antecedent was canceled. An antecedent is canceled if its property upon completion is . This option is not valid for multi-task continuations.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions.NotOnFaulted
member.summary: Specifies that the continuation task should not be scheduled if its antecedent threw an unhandled exception. An antecedent throws an unhandled exception if its property upon completion is . This option is not valid for multi-task continuations.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions.NotOnRanToCompletion
member.summary: Specifies that the continuation task should not be scheduled if its antecedent ran to completion. An antecedent runs to completion if its property upon completion is . This option is not valid for multi-task continuations.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions.OnlyOnCanceled
member.summary: Specifies that the continuation should be scheduled only if its antecedent was canceled. An antecedent is canceled if its property upon completion is . This option is not valid for multi-task continuations.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions.OnlyOnFaulted
member.summary: Specifies that the continuation task should be scheduled only if its antecedent threw an unhandled exception. An antecedent throws an unhandled exception if its property upon completion is . The option guarantees that the property in the antecedent is not . You can use that property to catch the exception and see which exception caused the task to fault. If you do not access the property, the exception is unhandled. Also, if you attempt to access the property of a task that has been canceled or has faulted, a new exception is thrown. This option is not valid for multi-task continuations.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions.OnlyOnRanToCompletion
member.summary: Specifies that the continuation should be scheduled only if its antecedent ran to completion. An antecedent runs to completion if its property upon completion is . This option is not valid for multi-task continuations.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions.PreferFairness
member.summary: A hint to a to schedule task in the order in which they were scheduled, so that tasks scheduled sooner are more likely to run sooner, and tasks scheduled later are more likely to run later.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskContinuationOptions.RunContinuationsAsynchronously
member.summary: Specifies that the continuation task should be run asynchronously. This option has precedence over .

member.name: T:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskCreationOptions
member.summary: Specifies flags that control optional behavior for the creation and execution of tasks.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskCreationOptions.AttachedToParent
member.summary: Specifies that a task is attached to a parent in the task hierarchy. By default, a child task (that is, an inner task created by an outer task) executes independently of its parent. You can use the option so that the parent and child tasks are synchronized. Note that if a parent task is configured with the option, the option in the child task has no effect, and the child task will execute as a detached child task. For more information, see Attached and Detached Child Tasks.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskCreationOptions.DenyChildAttach
member.summary: Specifies that any child task that attempts to execute as an attached child task (that is, it is created with the option) will not be able to attach to the parent task and will execute instead as a detached child task. For more information, see Attached and Detached Child Tasks.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskCreationOptions.HideScheduler
member.summary: Prevents the ambient scheduler from being seen as the current scheduler in the created task. This means that operations like StartNew or ContinueWith that are performed in the created task will see as the current scheduler.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskCreationOptions.LongRunning
member.summary: Specifies that a task will be a long-running, coarse-grained operation involving fewer, larger components than fine-grained systems. It provides a hint to the that oversubscription may be warranted. Oversubscription lets you create more threads than the available number of hardware threads. It also provides a hint to the task scheduler that an additional thread might be required for the task so that it does not block the forward progress of other threads or work items on the local thread-pool queue.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskCreationOptions.None
member.summary: Specifies that the default behavior should be used.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskCreationOptions.PreferFairness
member.summary: A hint to a to schedule a task in as fair a manner as possible, meaning that tasks scheduled sooner will be more likely to be run sooner, and tasks scheduled later will be more likely to be run later.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskCreationOptions.RunContinuationsAsynchronously
member.summary: Forces continuations added to the current task to be executed asynchronously. Note that the member is available in the enumeration starting with the .NET Framework 4.6.

member.name: T:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskFactory
member.summary: Provides support for creating and scheduling objects.

member.name: M:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskScheduler.TryExecuteTaskInline(System.Threading.Tasks.Task,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Determines whether the provided can be executed synchronously in this call, and if it can, executes it.
member.param: The to be executed.

A Boolean denoting whether or not task has previously been queued. If this parameter is True, then the task may have been previously queued (scheduled); if False, then the task is known not to have been queued, and this call is being made in order to execute the task inline without queuing it.
member.returns: A Boolean value indicating whether the task was executed inline.
member.exception: The argument is null.
The was already executed.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskStatus.Canceled
member.summary: The task acknowledged cancellation by throwing an OperationCanceledException with its own CancellationToken while the token was in signaled state, or the task's CancellationToken was already signaled before the task started executing. For more information, see Task Cancellation.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskStatus.Created
member.summary: The task has been initialized but has not yet been scheduled.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskStatus.Faulted
member.summary: The task completed due to an unhandled exception.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskStatus.RanToCompletion
member.summary: The task completed execution successfully.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskStatus.Running
member.summary: The task is running but has not yet completed.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskStatus.WaitingForActivation
member.summary: The task is waiting to be activated and scheduled internally by the .NET Framework infrastructure.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskStatus.WaitingForChildrenToComplete
member.summary: The task has finished executing and is implicitly waiting for attached child tasks to complete.

member.name: F:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskStatus.WaitingToRun

member.name: M:System.Type.GetType(System.String,System.Func{System.Reflection.AssemblyName,System.Reflection.Assembly},System.Func{System.Reflection.Assembly,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Type})
member.summary: Gets the type with the specified name, optionally providing custom methods to resolve the assembly and the type.
member.param: The name of the type to get. If the parameter is provided, the type name can be any string that is capable of resolving. If the parameter is provided or if standard type resolution is used, must be an assembly-qualified name (see ), unless the type is in the currently executing assembly or in Mscorlib.dll, in which case it is sufficient to supply the type name qualified by its namespace.

A method that locates and returns the assembly that is specified in . The assembly name is passed to as an object. If does not contain the name of an assembly, is not called. If is not supplied, standard assembly resolution is performed. Caution Do not pass methods from unknown or untrusted callers. Doing so could result in elevation of privilege for malicious code. Use only methods that you provide or that you are familiar with.

A method that locates and returns the type that is specified by from the assembly that is returned by or by standard assembly resolution. If no assembly is provided, the method can provide one. The method also takes a parameter that specifies whether to perform a case-insensitive search; is passed to that parameter. Caution Do not pass methods from unknown or untrusted callers.
member.returns: The type with the specified name, or if the type is not found.
member.exception: is .
A class initializer is invoked and throws an exception.

An error occurs when is parsed into a type name and an assembly name (for example, when the simple type name includes an unescaped special character). -or- represents a generic type that has a pointer type, a type, or as one of its type arguments. -or- represents a generic type that has an incorrect number of type arguments. -or- represents a generic type, and one of its type arguments does not satisfy the constraints for the corresponding type parameter.

member.summary: An integral type representing unsigned 8-bit integers with values between 0 and 255.

member.name: F:System.TypeCode.Char
member.summary: An integral type representing unsigned 16-bit integers with values between 0 and 65535. The set of possible values for the type corresponds to the Unicode character set.

member.summary: A type representing a date and time value.

member.name: F:System.TypeCode.DBNull
member.summary: A database null (column) value.

member.name: F:System.TypeCode.Decimal
member.summary: A simple type representing values ranging from 1.0 x 10 -28 to approximately 7.9 x 10 28 with 28-29 significant digits.

member.name: F:System.TypeCode.Double
member.summary: A floating point type representing values ranging from approximately 5.0 x 10 -324 to 1.7 x 10 308 with a precision of 15-16 digits.

member.name: F:System.TypeCode.Empty
member.summary: A null reference.

member.name: F:System.TypeCode.Int16
member.summary: An integral type representing signed 16-bit integers with values between -32768 and 32767.

member.name: F:System.TypeCode.Int32
member.summary: An integral type representing signed 32-bit integers with values between -2147483648 and 2147483647.

member.name: F:System.TypeCode.Int64
member.summary: An integral type representing signed 64-bit integers with values between -9223372036854775808 and 9223372036854775807.

member.name: F:System.TypeCode.Object
member.summary: A general type representing any reference or value type not explicitly represented by another .

member.name: F:System.TypeCode.SByte
member.summary: An integral type representing signed 8-bit integers with values between -128 and 127.

member.name: F:System.TypeCode.Single
member.summary: A floating point type representing values ranging from approximately 1.5 x 10 -45 to 3.4 x 10 38 with a precision of 7 digits.

member.name: F:System.TypeCode.String
member.summary: A sealed class type representing Unicode character strings.

member.name: F:System.TypeCode.UInt16
member.summary: An integral type representing unsigned 16-bit integers with values between 0 and 65535.

member.name: F:System.TypeCode.UInt32
member.summary: An integral type representing unsigned 32-bit integers with values between 0 and 4294967295.

member.name: F:System.TypeCode.UInt64
member.summary: An integral type representing unsigned 64-bit integers with values between 0 and 18446744073709551615.

member.name: M:System.Version.ToString
member.summary: Converts the value of the current object to its equivalent representation.
member.returns: The representation of the values of the major, minor, build, and revision components of the current object, as depicted in the following format. Each component is separated by a period character ('.'). Square brackets ('[' and ']') indicate a component that will not appear in the return value if the component is not defined: major.minor[.build[.revision]] For example, if you create a object using the constructor Version(1,1), the returned string is "1.1". If you create a object using the constructor Version(1,3,4,2), the returned string is "1.3.4.2".

member.name: M:System.Version.ToString(System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts the value of the current object to its equivalent representation. A specified count indicates the number of components to return.
member.param: The number of components to return. The ranges from 0 to 4.
member.returns:
The representation of the values of the major, minor, build, and revision components of the current object, each separated by a period character ('.'). The parameter determines how many components are returned. fieldCount
Return Value
0
An empty string ("").
1
major
2
major.minor
3
major.minor.build
4
major.minor.build.revision
For example, if you create object using the constructor Version(1,3,5), ToString(2) returns "1.3" and ToString(4) throws an exception.
member.exception: is less than 0, or more than 4. -or- is more than the number of components defined in the current object.
